snippet.title: Unplanned Tourism Development in Sub-Saharan Africa with Special Reference to Kenya
snippet.description:
* Unplanned Tourism Development in Sub-Saharan Africa with Special Reference to Kenya (Citations: 3)
Isaac Sindiga
In sub-Saharan Africa tourism has developed without planning. Three decades of such development increased tourist arrivals and foreign exchange receipts but led to serious environmental and socio-cultural problems and the degradation of the tourism product. This paper examines the development of tourism in sub-Saharan Africa using the Kenya example. After a period of unplanned expansion, Kenya's ...

snippet.title: Improving the Livelihoods of Women in the Developing World: Selected Perceptions of Women's Self-Help Groups in Western Kenya
snippet.description:
* Improving the Livelihoods of Women in the Developing World: Selected Perceptions of Women's Self-Help Groups in Western Kenya (Citations: 3)
Billy A. Jivetti, M. Craig Edwards
Development specialists agree that poverty in developing countries is a multidimensional phenomenon. The United Nations (2001) reported that the poorest of the world's poor are women. The Kenyan Government recognizes that poverty is area specific and interventions aimed at creating employment and reducing poverty must be localized. In Kenya, "women's self- help groups" have become popular avenues through ...
Published in 2008.

snippet.title: Variation in testosterone levels and male reproductive effort: Insight from a polygynous human population
snippet.description:
* Variation in testosterone levels and male reproductive effort: Insight from a polygynous human population (Citations: 6)
Alexandra Alvergne, Charlotte Faurie, Michel Raymond
Recent evidence suggests that, in humans, variations in testosterone (T) levels between men reflect their differential allocation in mating versus parenting efforts. However, most studies have been conducted in urbanized, monogamous populations, making generalizations from them questionable. This study addresses the question of whether indicators of male reproductive effort are associated with variations in salivary T levels in a polygynous ...
Journal: Hormones and Behavior - HORMONE BEHAV , vol. 56, no. 5, pp. 491-497, 2009

snippet.title: Social neuroendocrinology
snippet.description:
* Social neuroendocrinology (Citations: 2)
Sari M. van Anders, Neil V. Watson
In this paper we provide a critical review of research concerned with social/environmental mechanisms that modulate human neuroendocrine function. We survey research in four behavioral systems that have been shaped through evolution: competition, partnering, sex, and pregnancy/parenting. Generally, behavioral neuroendocrine research examines how hormones affect behavior. Instead, we focus on approaches that emphasize the effects of behavioral states ...
Journal: Human Nature-an Interdisciplinary Biosocial Perspective - HUM NATURE-INT BIOSOC PERSPEC , vol. 17, no. 2, pp. 212-237, 2006
